title.value: Generative Flow Networks: a Markov Chain Perspective
title.justification: This is the title as given in the paper's header.
title.quote: Generative Flow Networks: a Markov Chain Perspective

extractions.description: This paper explores the intersection between Generative Flow Networks (GFlowNets) and Markov Chain Monte Carlo methods (MCMC), positioning GFlowNets under the same theoretical framework as MCMC methods and highlighting both their similarities and differences. The authors introduce a new perspective for GFlowNets using Markov chains, showing how GFlowNets can be viewed as recurrent Markov chains regardless of the state space, and extend the theoretical underpinning of GFlowNets to general state spaces.

type.justification: The paper primarily focuses on formalizing the connection between Generative Flow Networks and Markov chains from a theoretical perspective, rather than conducting empirical experiments.
type.quote: In this paper, we formalize this connection and offer a new perspective for GFlowNets using Markov chains, showing a unifying view for GFlowNets regardless of the nature of the state space as recurrent Markov chains.

name.justification: The primary focus is on modeling probability distributions using Generative Flow Networks and Markov Chains.
name.quote: While Markov chain Monte Carlo methods (MCMC) provide a general framework to sample from a probability distribution defined up to normalization, they often suffer from slow convergence to the target distribution when the latter is highly multi-modal.

name.justification: The paper introduces Generative Flow Networks and discusses their generative modeling capabilities.
name.quote: A Generative Flow Network (GFlowNet) is a generative model that treats the generation of an object as a sequential decision making problem (Bengio et al., 2021a,b).

name.justification: The paper positions Generative Flow Networks under the same theoretical framework as Markov Chain Monte Carlo methods and discusses the relationship between the two.
name.quote: While Markov chain Monte Carlo methods (MCMC) provide a general framework to sample from a probability distribution defined up to normalization, they often suffer from slow convergence to the target distribution when the latter is highly multi-modal.

name.justification: The paper focuses extensively on Generative Flow Networks and their perspectives from Markov Chains.
name.quote: Recently, Generative Flow Networks (GFlowNets; Bengio et al., 2021a,b) have been proposed as an alternative framework to sample from distributions defined up to normalization, when the samples in question have a natural compositional structure.

is_contributed.justification: The model was proposed in prior research by Bengio et al., 2021.
is_contributed.quote: Even though GFlowNets were originally introduced from the perspective of flow networks (Bengio et al., 2021a), most of the recent advances completely ignore the need to work with flows, and work directly as a Markovian process, with conditions heavily inspired by the literature on Markov chains (e.g., the detailed balance conditions; Bengio et al., 2021b).

is_executed.justification: The paper does not carry out specific computational experiments running the models.
is_executed.quote: In this paper, we formalize this connection and offer a new perspective for GFlowNets using Markov chains, showing a unifying view for GFlowNets regardless of the nature of the state space as recurrent Markov chains.

is_compared.justification: The paper compares Generative Flow Networks (GFlowNets) to Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods.
is_compared.quote: One of the main advantages of viewing GFlowNets from the perspective of Markov chains is that it places them under the same theoretical framework as MCMC methods, highlighting the similarities and differences between both methods.
